Award.AwardTitle: REU Sites: Anthropology by the Wire: Community Ethnography through Multimedia Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this REU project, the PI-team recruits a diverse group of students drawn primarily from area community colleges for anthropological research projects on neighborhoods in Baltimore utilizing anthropological methods through the lens of a public anthropology that demonstrates the relevance of anthropology to both student researchers and to community participants. Over the course of 6 weeks in the summer, 15 students attend seminars held at Towson University that are led by faculty from Towson and from area community colleges. In addition, participants attend workshops facilitated by community residents and organizers introducing them to field sites in Baltimore's neighborhoods. While working on their own ethnographic projects utilizing visual anthropology, participant observation, interviews and archival work, students simultaneously collect and analyze data with the assistance of, and in cooperation with, community participants. These projects will take many forms, but all include multimedia representations of the lives of people in communities that can be utilized by people in their own efforts to develop their communities. When participants leave Towson, they spend the next months analyzing data and completing their projects for presentation to the community the following May. During this time, they maintain a virtual community with other participants, including faculty and community associates, for additional collaboration and mentorship. After the end of the REU summer, faculty remain in contact with student cohorts in order to facilitate transition to a 4-year university and to assist with efforts to disseminate results.

Intellectual merit: 1) publishable undergraduate research papers; 2) reflexive, documentary multimedia posted online that demonstrate the benefits of university-community partnerships for undergraduate research and for community-defined goals; and 3). a pedagogical model for general education courses that include an original research component.

Broader impacts: 1) multimedia presentations created for public audiences highlighting the lives, problems and aspirations of Baltimore residents in their home communities; 2) electronic networks of students, faculty and community organizers interested in community-based research and dissemination; and 3) a network of faculty from Towson and area community colleges interested in encouraging community college students to pursue research and post-graduate work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anthropology By The Wire is a multi-media research project on urban and visual anthropology in Baltimore that is part of a National Science Foundation Research Experience for Undergraduates grant at Towson University. In this project, students conduct research on neighborhoods in Baltimore utilizing anthropological methods through the lens of a public anthropology with a variety of digital media. Data in the form of videos, photos, audio, links and text represent the outcome and mediation of those endeavors.  REU participants were mostly drawn from local community colleges for this project, and many of them lived in the neighborhoods where we conducted research.  

Over three years, REU participants partnered with a variety of community organizations to collect data that could help people in communities advance their own projects to improve the lives of people in their neighborhoods.  These included several, different sites, each with its own challenge to a collaborative, qualitative project.  In the first, "Sharp Leadenhall," REU participants worked to document the historic, African American neighborhood of Sharp Leadenhall in South Baltimore as it experiences various forms of pressure from the neighborhoods around it.  At the second site, "JACQUES," REU participants worked with clients at an HIV outreach center to document everyday life with HIV in order to analyze the experience of HIV+ people in Baltimore while helping clients to break the stigma the disease has in their neighborhoods.  At the third site, "Baltimore Steel," REU participants interviewed and filmed former employees of RG Steel, at one time the largest steel manufacturing plant in the United States and the symbol of Baltimore's industrial past.  Working with former employees to document their struggle and their changing identities yielded data on the nature of post-industrial Baltimore.  Finally, REU participants worked with a local nonprofit, Wide Angle Youth Media, to examine the production of multimedia, documentary material among Baltimore residents.  At this site, REU participants analyzed how residents of Baltimore see themselves and how they portray social problems plaguing their neighborhoods.  

Work at these sites yielded multimedia data that is available under a Creative Commons license on anthropologybythewire.com, and on a Youtube site: "https://www.youtube.com/user/anthbythewire".  REU participants disseminated data through a variety of media and venues, including published articles, conference papers, film festivals and gallery showing.  Most of the REU participants have gone on their education, whether that involved transferring to a 4-year college from their community college or going to graduate school in anthropology or a related field (e.g., cultural geography).  

This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grant No. 1156767.  Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.
